articles.headline: Alex Jones Seeks to Liquidate His Assets to Pay Damages to Sandy Hook Families
articles.snippet: But money to the families would fall far short of the more than $1.4 billion they were awarded by juries for Mr. Jones’s lies about the 2012 school massacre.
articles.abstract: But money to the families would fall far short of the more than $1.4 billion they were awarded by juries for Mr. Jones’s lies about the 2012 school massacre.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Infowars conspiracy theorist Alex Jones is seeking permission from a bankruptcy court to liquidate his personal assets and deliver the proceeds to the Sandy Hook families who are owed more than $1.4 billion in damages for his lies about the 2012 school shooting.

articles.headline: Hunter Biden Is on Trial, but All Eyes Are on the Biden Women
articles.snippet: The women called to testify have at different times tried to support a man whose history of addiction continues to hit them with shrapnel.
articles.abstract: The women called to testify have at different times tried to support a man whose history of addiction continues to hit them with shrapnel.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the verdict in Hunter Biden’s gun trial.
articles.byline: By Zach Montague and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: The Cats of Old San Juan Are Being Run Out of Town. Locals Can Empathize.
articles.snippet: A federal plan to remove feral cats from a historic site in Puerto Rico’s capital has upset some residents, who are also feeling pushed out as housing costs soar.
articles.abstract: A federal plan to remove feral cats from a historic site in Puerto Rico’s capital has upset some residents, who are also feeling pushed out as housing costs soar.
articles.lead_paragraph: Feral cats have roamed the blue cobblestone streets of Old San Juan for as long as anyone can remember. They meander around a historic fortress that looms over San Juan Bay, hiding from the hot sun under sea grape bushes.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei and Erika P. Rodriguez

articles.headline: Trump Vows to Lower Prices. Some of His Policies May Raise Them.
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump has not released a detailed economic plan. But three of his key proposals would push prices up, economists say.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump has not released a detailed economic plan. But three of his key proposals would push prices up, economists say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump routinely blames President Biden for higher prices at the grocery store and everywhere else Americans shop, and promises to “fix it.”
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan

articles.headline: Energy Drinks Boost Ukraine’s Soldiers, and Its Economy
articles.snippet: Cans packed with caffeine and branded with patriotic machismo have become an essential antidote to the stresses of war.
articles.abstract: Cans packed with caffeine and branded with patriotic machismo have become an essential antidote to the stresses of war.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a sunny morning, deep in the forests of western Ukraine where the war barely reaches, 16,000 cans of a new energy drink, Volia, rolled off the assembly line every hour at the Morshynska beverage factory.

articles.headline: The British Aren’t Coming. They’re Here.
articles.snippet: As a historic presidential election looms, several of America’s largest and most powerful newsrooms are now being led by English journalists. Why?
articles.abstract: As a historic presidential election looms, several of America’s largest and most powerful newsrooms are now being led by English journalists. Why?
articles.lead_paragraph: The news business is in upheaval. A presidential election is barreling down the pike. Facing financial challenges and political division, several of America’s largest news organizations have turned over the reins to editors who prize relentless reporting on a budget.

articles.headline: The Best Way to Get a Refund When Your Airline’s Wi-Fi Is Terrible
articles.snippet: We compiled shortcuts and links for every big U.S. carrier — and some little-known tips that should make it easier to get your money back.
articles.abstract: We compiled shortcuts and links for every big U.S. carrier — and some little-known tips that should make it easier to get your money back.
articles.lead_paragraph: When an airline sells you a service, you should be able to receive a refund if it doesn’t deliver. But when is it not worth your time to even bother asking for one?

articles.headline: Israel Rescues 4 Hostages in Assault That Killed Scores of Gazans
articles.snippet: The news was met with jubilation in Israel, where tensions over the hostages’ safety have been rising in recent months.
articles.abstract: The news was met with jubilation in Israel, where tensions over the hostages’ safety have been rising in recent months.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israeli soldiers and special operations police rescued four hostages from Gaza on Saturday amid a heavy air and ground assault and flew them back to Israel by helicopter to be reunited with their families. The news was met with jubilation in Israel, where anxieties over the fate of the roughly 120 remaining captives have been rising after eight months of war.
articles.byline: By Aaron Boxerman, Raja Abdulrahim and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Where O.J. Simpson Found Acceptance, No Questions Asked
articles.snippet: Las Vegas became a refuge that many believe Mr. Simpson did not deserve in his final years. There, he found an unlikely group of friends.
articles.abstract: Las Vegas became a refuge that many believe Mr. Simpson did not deserve in his final years. There, he found an unlikely group of friends.
articles.lead_paragraph: O.J. Simpson, even in his final years, was somewhat of a spectacle.

articles.headline: Is Your Driving Being Secretly Scored?
articles.snippet: The insurance industry, hungry for insights into how people drive, has turned to automakers and smartphone apps like Life360.
articles.abstract: The insurance industry, hungry for insights into how people drive, has turned to automakers and smartphone apps like Life360.
articles.lead_paragraph: You know you have a credit score. Did you know that you might also have a driver score?

articles.headline: What Retail Apocalypse? Shopping Centers Are Making a Comeback.
articles.snippet: Vacancy is the lowest it has been in two decades, at 5.4 percent, according to a recent report. The properties are thriving even as retailers like Macy’s and Express shutter many stores.
articles.abstract: Vacancy is the lowest it has been in two decades, at 5.4 percent, according to a recent report. The properties are thriving even as retailers like Macy’s and Express shutter many stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shopping center landlords have found themselves in a wholly unfamiliar position: For the first time in 20 years, demand for retail space outstrips supply.

articles.headline: Hey, Siri! Let’s Talk About How Apple Is Giving You an A.I. Makeover.
articles.snippet: Apple, a latecomer to artificial intelligence, has struck a deal with OpenAI and developed tools to improve its Siri voice assistant, which it is set to showcase on Monday.
articles.abstract: Apple, a latecomer to artificial intelligence, has struck a deal with OpenAI and developed tools to improve its Siri voice assistant, which it is set to showcase on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Each June, Apple unveils its newest software features for the iPhone at its futuristic Silicon Valley campus. But at its annual developer conference on Monday, the company will shine a spotlight on a feature that isn’t new: Siri, its talking assistant, which has been around for more than a decade.

articles.headline: Israel’s Euphoria Over Hostage Rescue May Be Fleeting
articles.snippet: The operation conducted by Israel’s military to free four hostages resulted in a high death toll among Palestinians and has not resolved the challenges facing the Israeli government.
articles.abstract: The operation conducted by Israel’s military to free four hostages resulted in a high death toll among Palestinians and has not resolved the challenges facing the Israeli government.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, Israelis had heard only about hostages being killed or declared dead in Gaza. The “lucky” families were those whose loved ones’ remains were retrieved by soldiers, at great risk, and brought home to Israel for burial.

articles.headline: She’s Fighting to Save America’s ‘Last Best Place’ From Suicide
articles.snippet: Montana’s suicide rate has been the highest in the U.S. for the past three years. Most of the deaths involved firearms. But suicide rarely registers in the national debate over guns.
articles.abstract: Montana’s suicide rate has been the highest in the U.S. for the past three years. Most of the deaths involved firearms. But suicide rarely registers in the national debate over guns.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a typical day, Ali Mullen races from her job at the county health department in Helena, Mont., to pick up dinner for her three children, heads home to feed them and then goes back out for a violin lesson or a school play, crisscrossing the small city in her aging S.U.V., with a rainbow bumper sticker that reads “You Are Loved.”
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Tailyr Irvine

articles.headline: Their City Has a Plaque From Putin. They Want Zelensky to Tear It Down.
articles.snippet: Some residents of Bari, Italy, hope Ukraine’s president will drop by while at a nearby summit to help rid them of a memento of links with Russia.
articles.abstract: Some residents of Bari, Italy, hope Ukraine’s president will drop by while at a nearby summit to help rid them of a memento of links with Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: A small copper plaque mounted across the piazza from the Basilica of St. Nicholas in Bari, Italy, pledges “friendship and cooperation” between the city and the Russian people. It is signed by someone who, for the past two years in Europe, has pursued anything but: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

articles.headline: The Quiet Voice in R.F.K. Jr.’s Ear: A Former Aide to the Clintons
articles.snippet: Jay Carson spent years as a Democratic insider. Disillusioned, he left politics for Hollywood and became friends with Robert F. Kennedy Jr. — whose campaign he is now helping to steer.
articles.abstract: Jay Carson spent years as a Democratic insider. Disillusioned, he left politics for Hollywood and became friends with Robert F. Kennedy Jr. — whose campaign he is now helping to steer.
articles.lead_paragraph: In his outsider bid for the White House, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is flanked by a team of unlikely political characters: new age health gurus, anti-vaccine activists, social media influencers, veterans of fringe third-party campaigns, cryptocurrency evangelists and militant environmentalists.

articles.headline: In Calling Elections in France, Macron Makes a Huge Gamble
articles.snippet: The president has challenged voters to test the sincerity of their support for the far right in European elections. Were the French letting off steam, or did they really mean it?
articles.abstract: The president has challenged voters to test the sincerity of their support for the far right in European elections. Were the French letting off steam, or did they really mean it?
articles.lead_paragraph: On the face of it, there is little logic in calling an election from a position of great weakness. But that is what President Emmanuel Macron has done by calling a snap parliamentary election in France on the back of a humiliation by the far right.

articles.headline: States Take Up A.I. Regulation Amid Federal Standstill
articles.snippet: California legislators have made the biggest push to pass new laws to rein in the technology. Colorado passed one protecting consumers.
articles.abstract: California legislators have made the biggest push to pass new laws to rein in the technology. Colorado passed one protecting consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in California last month advanced about 30 new measures on artificial intelligence aimed at protecting consumers and jobs, one of the biggest efforts yet to regulate the new technology.

articles.headline: For an Older Homeless Population, a New Type of Care
articles.snippet: Programs are sprouting across the country to provide nursing home and rehabilitation services to homeless people who would otherwise shuttle between hospitals and the street.
articles.abstract: Programs are sprouting across the country to provide nursing home and rehabilitation services to homeless people who would otherwise shuttle between hospitals and the street.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five years on the Phoenix streets battered Vance Blair’s body. His vision dimmed, his speech slowed, and his hands began to twitch. A bulging pelvis revealed the need for hernia surgery, and the vacant lot where he slept was no place to keep dressings clean.

articles.headline: A Democrat, Siding With the G.O.P., Is Removing Limits on Political Cash at ‘Breathtaking’ Speed
articles.snippet: The Federal Election Commission has long done little more than reach deadlock, but an ascendant bloc of three Republicans and one Democrat has begun to unravel longstanding restraints.
articles.abstract: The Federal Election Commission has long done little more than reach deadlock, but an ascendant bloc of three Republicans and one Democrat has begun to unravel longstanding restraints.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, America’s campaign watchdog agency was a portrait of dysfunction. Divided equally between three Republicans and three Democrats, the Federal Election Commission deadlocked so often it became a political punchline as investigations languished, enforcement slowed and updated guidelines for the internet era stalled.
